results.content: I greatly enjoy the course! Amazing tutor, helped me with suggestions on how to solve problems I had with running my project. It is so much fun and interesting! I did some courses on online platforms on Python and Django, this one is the best!
results.content_html: I greatly enjoy the course! Amazing tutor, helped me with suggestions on how to solve problems I had with running my project. It is so much fun and interesting! I did some courses on online platforms on Python and Django, this one is the best!

results.content:
Mezzanine is a powerful plate-form to work on. My ratings are about the contents of this course only.

Best topics:-
1.) Customizing search, admin & tinymce.
2.) Three mezzanine homepage configuration.
3.) Cartridge install and set up.
4.) Adding an app and customizing all templates from that app.

Missing:- 
1. No form built for users to post blog:- Sir, user is not going to get into our admin login to post a blog. How about building a blog-post-form and then show it on our blog list page.
2. How to add mezzanine to an existing project or as an app to an existing project.
3.) Good Video Quality.

Surprise Benefit:- I got the course completion certificate for an incomplete course. Yes, the e-commerce section is still incomplete. Hoping for new tutorials very soon.Thanks

response.content: Thanks Rampal for the detailed review. I don't see a scenario where I would want users posting blog posts unless they are registered editors or admins on the site, so I probably wouldn't create this or any public blog post form. Logging in for it would be essential in my opinion. Adding Mezzanine to an existing project I am happy to add and would have done so ASAP if requested. Sorry you found the course only worthy of two stars.
response.content_html: Thanks Rampal for the detailed review. I don't see a scenario where I would want users posting blog posts unless they are registered editors or admins on the site, so I probably wouldn't create this or any public blog post form. Logging in for it would be essential in my opinion. Adding Mezzanine to an existing project I am happy to add and would have done so ASAP if requested. Sorry you found the course only worthy of two stars.

results.content: This was exactly the kind of crash course I was interested in. Thank you Travis for putting it together. It's definitely useful to have some understanding of django before starting. The course is generally logically structured and the fact that the example project is quite simple helps a lot.

results.content:
One of the few Mezzanine courses I've been able to find and this course is a pretty comprehensive review of Mezzanine basics.  Travis is a very engaging teacher and his explanations are easy to follow and through.

Highly recommend the course.
results.content_html:
One of the few Mezzanine courses I've been able to find and this course is a pretty comprehensive review of Mezzanine basics. Travis is a very engaging teacher and his explanations are easy to follow and through.

Highly recommend the course.

results.content: Very happy with the whole experience, somehow, I followed every word, made every click, and can't believe that I was seeing the same thing.  Mezzanine seems to me to be an absolute gang-buster combo of tools, and frankly, compared to the NPM world of version hurt, I am just really thankful to be back in a less insane world of Python where a couple of pip commands can get you into a whole virtual environment of tools that actually work together. (How many dependencies and sub-dependencies does npm bring in to handle ES6 for example?  I think it was over 300, and surprise surprise, galloping cucumber needed a different version of crawling carat - give me a break!)
results.content_html: Very happy with the whole experience, somehow, I followed every word, made every click, and can't believe that I was seeing the same thing. Mezzanine seems to me to be an absolute gang-buster combo of tools, and frankly, compared to the NPM world of version hurt, I am just really thankful to be back in a less insane world of Python where a couple of pip commands can get you into a whole virtual environment of tools that actually work together. (How many dependencies and sub-dependencies does npm bring in to handle ES6 for example? I think it was over 300, and surprise surprise, galloping cucumber needed a different version of crawling carat - give me a break!)

results.content: Everything is spot on. Its what I ever wanted to learn with Django and Python, something easier to digest. But I really love Python and Django though
